prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Initiating Panel proceedings—Contents of the motion

para.paratext: A motion for transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 should comply with the requirements of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure applicable to motions.[1] A motion for transfer should set forth the grounds for the motion.[2] The Panel Rules require that the motion be in the form of a pleading, that briefly describes the action or relief sought from the Panel.[3] The motion should be limited to the statement of facts supporting transfer under the standards of the statute. Argument of those facts and the citation of authority supporting the motions should be made in a separate memorandum.[4] A sample motion appears in Appendix A.[5]

Specifically, it is prudent to allege the requirements for transfer set forth in the statute and allege the common facts that justify transfer. A motion with sufficient detail is set forth in Appendix A.

Failure to allege the specific common facts may result in denial of the motion. In one case the Panel did deny a motion for transfer on the grounds that the motion and the supporting brief did not establish common facts supporting transfer.[6] The Panel did grant the parties leave to reapply if circumstances later warranted, but transfer was denied.[7]

The motion for transfer need not identify the transferee district to which the moving party feels the actions should be transferred. The Panel does value the views of the moving party, however, as well as any other parties, on the transfer question, so identifying a transferee district is useful. The failure of any of the parties to identify a preferred transferee district may indicate to the Panel that transfer is not appropriate.[8] This might also, however, indicate that the parties are seeking transfer for the benefits of centralization without having a preference for a particular form. If so, this point should be made explicitly rather than by silence.

As with all motions, it is a good idea to set forth clearly what you want the Panel to do. In one case the Panel denied a motion for transfer, at least in part, because the court could not discern what the movant wanted done.[9] The Panel noted that the motion “suffers from a lack of precision” and then attempted to determine what was sought.[10] Obviously, if the movant had clearly stated what was sought, it would have been more likely to have that specific relief considered by the Panel.

A motion for transfer may be withdrawn, and the Panel has given effect to such withdrawal, coupled with the absence of objection by the other parties to strike the matter from its calendar. Because the Panel may entertain transfer on its own initiative, withdrawal of a transfer motion will not necessarily accomplish this result, however.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The formal requirements of motions in federal court are discussed in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice (7th ed. 2016).
